events.title: The London Protocol established Greece's independence
events.description: The London Protocol was signed by Britain, France, and Russia, recognizing Greece as an independent sovereign state, ending its war of independence from the Ottoman Empire.
events.significance: This marked the formal recognition of Greek independence, a major step in the decline of Ottoman authority in Europe.

events.title: First Tour de France begins
events.description: The inaugural Tour de France bicycle race started in Paris as a 6-stage race over 2,428 kilometers, which would become the world's most famous and challenging cycling race.
events.significance: The beginning of what would become a globally significant sporting event and cultural tradition.

events.title: NY State Assembly refuses Socialist membership
events.description: The New York State Assembly voted to expel five Socialist assembly members, reflecting tensions during the Red Scare post World War I.
events.significance: An example of political suppression during a period of fear of communist influence in the US.

events.title: Egyptian Revolution begins
events.description: A group of Egyptian army officers, known as the Free Officers Movement, led a coup d'Ã©tat that eventually led to the overthrow of King Farouk and the establishment of a republic.
events.significance: Marked the end of the monarchy in Egypt and the beginning of a new political era.

events.title: The Piper Alpha disaster
events.description: An explosion and fire on the North Sea oil platform Piper Alpha resulted in the death of 167 workers, making it one of the deadliest offshore oil disasters in history.
events.significance: Led to major changes in offshore oil platform safety regulations worldwide.
